p: FIV is the pathogen of the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) in felines. [ 22– 24] It exhibits biological properties very similar to HIV, and as such it is considered a useful non-primate model to study HIV infection, and to test anti-HIV vaccine [ 25– 27] and drugs. Analogously to HIV, FIV [ 28] enters cells thanks to gp36, the envelope glycoprotein [ 29– 31] showing the same structural and functional properties of gp41. [ 32– 34] C8, including three equally spaced Trp residues in its sequence, elicits antiviral activity preventing the entry of the virus in the host cells. C8 is endowed with strong membrane binding property, and many evidence show that its antiviral action is based on its ability to prevent the interaction of gp36 MPER with the surface of the host cell. [ 35]
